unnormalised: The Union Budget 2024-25, presented on 01/02/2024, projects a fiscal deficit of 5.1% of GDP. This is a reduction from the revised estimate of 5.8% for FY 2023-24. The budget allocated ₹11.11 lakh crore for infrastructure development, a 3% increase YoY. The government aims to bring the fiscal deficit below 4.5% by FY 2025-26.
normalised: The Union Budget two thousand and twenty four to twenty five, presented on first february two thousand and twenty four, projects a fiscal deficit of five point one percent of G-D-P. This is a reduction from the revised estimate of five point eight percent for F-Y two thousand twenty three to twenty four. The budget allocated rupee eleven point eleven lakh crore for infrastructure development, a three percent increase Y-o-Y. The government aims to bring the fiscal deficit below four point five percent by F-Y two thousand twenty five to twenty six.

unnormalised: Revenue receipts for FY 2024-25 are estimated at ₹30 lakh crore, while total expenditure is projected at ₹47.66 lakh crore. Direct tax collections are expected to grow by 12% in FY25. The budget proposes no changes to the existing tax rates. Allocations for key sectors such as healthcare and education saw increases of 8% and 10% respectively.
normalised: Revenue receipts for F-Y two thousand twenty four to twenty five are estimated at rupee thirty lakh crore, while total expenditure is projected at rupee forty seven point sixty six lakh crore. Direct tax collections are expected to grow by twelve percent in F-Y twenty five. The budget proposes no changes to the existing tax rates. Allocations for key sectors such as healthcare and education saw increases of eight percent and ten percent respectively.

unnormalised: The disinvestment target for FY 2024-25 has been set at Rs 50000 crore. Market analysts at SBI predict a positive impact on investor sentiment following the budget announcement. The Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman emphasized the government's commitment to fiscal consolidation and sustainable economic growth.
normalised: The disinvestment target for F-Y two thousand twenty four to twenty five has been set at rupees fifty thousand crore. Market analysts at S-B-I predict a positive impact on investor sentiment following the budget announcement. The Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman emphasized the government's commitment to fiscal consolidation and sustainable economic growth.
